title: Can Social Bookmarks Improve Web Search?

author: Paul Heymann, Department of Computer Science, Stanford University

segmentation: So I'm actually going to start this talk with a little bit of a digression, so as opposed.
Images Social book working.
I'm going to start by talking.
About collaborative tagging systems as a whole, which is sort of a broader area and collaborative tagging systems have gotten really popular over the past couple of years.

There's really been an explosion of interest in them, and one of the reasons is that if you have a video sharing site or an image sharing site where you want to search, it's not usually easy to do search on that kind of site.
So what you can do is you can allow users to add tags.
So for example, I've got the video Spaghetti Town, and some users have added receptionists and spaghetti and so on.
And then if you if you want to provide full text search all you do is you index those tags and suddenly users can search your videos, so that's.

One example of a tagging site, Amazon is another example of a popular site that you stack uses tags, so some of these tags are pretty obvious, so the book is the set of books I should say is the art of computer programming and it's been tagged as algorithms, which would probably be pretty obvious given the other metadata that Amazon probably has.
But it's also been tagged as classic, which might be less obvious, so it's a classic text.
Computer science.
The topic of this particular talk is social bookmarking and a social bookmarking site is where you're annotating URLs rather than annotating.

You know retail items or videos or what have you, so up at the top there, I have Strunk and White's elements of style, and it's been tagged as writing in reference in English and so forth, so the reason that we care about this is that these sites have gotten really big over the past couple of years.
Delicious has over 2 million users.
There are other very popular social bookmarking sites like StumbleUpon that have many users as well.
And the question is, given the fact that millions of users are just labeling data for us.
You know, can we use this?
Data to improve web search.
So that's the general idea.
And this actually breaks down.
Found into into a couple of sub questions, so it's not just you know can improve web search, but it's also is this a big enough data source?
As I said, there are millions of users annotating data, but you know the web is billions of URLs, so if it's a small portion of that then it may not be particularly valuable to use this data.

Another big question is whether the URLs are valuable for some particular reason, so if their recent or they tend to occur a lot in search results, it may be valuable to know that users are bookmarking them.
Disproportionate to the number of URLs that we actually have information about.
And the final big question is whether the tags that are annotating these URLs are redundant for one reason or another, so.

If you're a search engine, it's the case that in addition to a number of other data sources, you have a lot of text about a given page, so I have cnn.com up there and you first of all have the text of cnn.com, which is probably thousands or 10s of thousands of words.
But you also have all of the forward links and all the backlinks and all of the associated text about that page, and so you're drowning in a sea of text.
And the question is, if users are adding two or three tags to bookmarks that are bookmarking cnn.com.
Are we?
Are we learning more information about this page so?
That's the basic.
Outline of our question and the way that we went about answering it was we extracted a set of bookmarks or posts.
We use the two terms synonymously from delicious and each book marker post consists of 1 user.
For example Paul tagging a particular URL like bbc.co.uk with a set of tags like news and UK and there's some timestamp which indicates that a user is decided to bookmark it at a particular time.
Now we then subdivide each of those bookmarks into a list of triples.
And each of those triples is just a user tag URL triple, and these are the two basic data types that we deal with when we do our analysis.
But to answer the question of whether tags are redundant, we also need something other than just the content that we can get from delicious.
And So what we do is we actually do real time web crawling.

So we retrieve a post so we get the posts in real time from delicious and within about 2 hours of those bookmarks being posted, we actually crawl the page text all of as many of the forward links as we can and the backlinks, so all within 2 hours.
And the reason we need to do it within 2 hours.
Is because a lot of these pages are fast moving pages, so they're changing for all sorts of reasons.
Cnn.com's front page is changing pretty often, and so if we don't for our analysis want to end up in this situation where somebody has tagged something with the right tag.
But then the content has changed and it appears to be an irrelevant or meaningless tag.
So.
So that's how we went about getting our data.

And the answer to the first question as to whether there's enough of this data is that there are about 120,000 posts per day they get posted to delicious, which is certainly a lot of posts per day, and the only thing that we can really compare it to his blog post.
So the reason why we think it's probably a fair comparison to compare to blog posts is that you know they're sort of providing similar information.
They are providing URLs that are new that are interesting, and they're also providing user commentary on those URLs.
So it turns out there's about an order of magnitude more URLs in.
And more posts in blog posts than there are in social bookmarking systems.
Even if you assume maybe that there are two or three times this in all of the social bookmarking systems.
So when you actually extrapolate this over the over the course of the life of Delicious, you end up with about 100 million posts in total.
You know, maybe it's 60 million posts.
Maybe it's 150 million posts an when you filter that down and make some make some assumptions, you end up with 10s of millions of unique URLs that are probably in the system and.

Systems like it now that's actually sort of a small number compared to the size of the web, so no one actually agrees on what the size of the web is, and it's somewhat of a meaningless question because there's all sorts of dynamic content, but arguably the size of the web is probably 10s of billions of pages, and this is probably a thousandth of that.
Another question that we also want to know as opposed to just what the current size is, is how fast it's growing.
So in these two scatter plots on the left and right side, we actually show the growth rate of of delicious.
Said two different time periods.
So in in the left side you can actually see the time period from August 2005 to August 2006, an linear scale and also the post per day on the Y axis in linear scale.
And what you see there is that between August and August you end up with.

An increase of 30,000 to 90,000 posts per day, so it's tripling in that time period, so that's actually a pretty big increase, but if you then look at the subsequent period of about seven or eight months between November and July, November 2006 to July 2007, things are relatively stable.
You're not seeing an acceleration in the number of posts per day.
It could be that people are posting privately or other other things, but.
The phenomenon seems to have stabilized by that point.
So what this suggests is that we can't really predict where where social bookmarking will be a year from now.
So actually if you look at this tick right there in December 9, 2005, that's actually where where delicious gets acquired by Yahoo.
So it appears to be the case that being acquired triples the number of posts per day, and you know, there.
Maybe there's promotion and stuff like that and the Joker under lab?
Is that maybe.
If Yahoo gets acquired, then you know the number of posts per day will increase again.
But in any case, we have no idea one way or another, whether you know this.
This phenomenon will increase substantially or will stay about the same size.
Now, rather than just caring about the wrong number of URLs, we may actually care about whether those URLs are new, whether they're recently modified, and so forth.
And So what we did was when a URL was posted delicious, we search for it using the Yahoo Search API, and we checked whether it was in Yahoo search.
So the theory was that if it was not yet indexed than it was a new and sort of interesting page, and so about 57.5% of the URLs that.
We search for.
We're actually we're actually in the Yahoo search API, but the other 42.5% were missing, so these seem to be new pages that nobody's indexed an.
The reason you know, so we actually looked continuously.
We did a series of searches over the next six months to see whether they would later get indexed.
So the argument here is that if a URL was originally not indexed, and then it later gets indexed, then it was something that was worth indexing.
We can't really say anything about things that were never indexed because you know.
They may be really good.
They may be really bad, but if something was searched for and we didn't find it, but then it was indexed later than our argument is that it is actually worth indexing.
So within about four weeks we increase the we get about 12.75% index and within another within six months we get an additional 12.75% indexed.
So overall about 25% of the posts and delicious our new URLs that would be indexed later and then you could index.
If you had this information.
So.
The other question is for this 57.5% we look at how recently it's been updated.
Have recently it's been modified and this ends up being sort of a tough thing to do because pages lie about how recently they've been modified all the time.
You know they for caching purposes they'll change their modification dates and you know many of them just don't give a modification date.
So what we did was we used the search API again an we look at the modification date because search engines need to know roughly when something was modified.
Or incremental crawling and stuff like that an the result is this histogram is on the bottom here.
So what happens is for example, if I post a URL like cnn.com and say it was last modified a day ago, then it will slightly increase the bar above one day.
So this is a histogram of the recency of URLs and Delicious.
And also the times are in log scale.
So it turns out that most of the things that are posted is delicious are posted within about.
About a day ago, an you know or most recently updated about a day ago or were most recently updated about 10 days ago so, but without any sort of comparison, this isn't.
Terribly valuable fact, so we actually compared to two things to try to give an impression of how this relates to the web as a whole.

So we compared to Open Directory, which is sort of a reasonable approximation, as the web of the web as a whole, but it's sort of an older set of pages an it turns out that social bookmarking URLs are much more recent in terms of how often they're updated.
How you know how new they are and stuff like that.
Then Open Directory Pages, open directory pages are.
Modified, you know 10 days ago 100 days ago.
It's a it's much more skewed to the right.
The other thing that we compared to was Yahoo search results.
So what we did was we took the AOL query.
The query log data set and we randomly sampled queries.

So for example, you might actually randomly sample with the query American Idol for example, and then we would search for that query and we would take the top 10 search results and we would then figure out what the modification dates for them were and put them in this histogram an what you see is that actually the recency of search results.
Is actually really similar to the recency of things that are posted in Delicious and what this suggests is one of two things.

Actually, depending on how cynical you are, I suppose the first possibility is that the delicious URLs are actually a really good source of URLs for web search there about the recency of URLs that search likes to give out, so they'd be great.
The other possibility is that web search is actually the source of these URLs, and so the reason that you're getting these.
These similar frequency distributions is because the fact that people are searching and then they're posting them.
We think that because of the fact that many of these URLs are not initially indexed, that it seems unlikely that all of them are getting discovered by search.
But we do know it could be either way.
The final thing.

So I've talked about the number of URLs and I've talked about the usefulness of those URLs, but I promised I talk a little bit about tagging and it turns out that tagging, at least for URLs, ends up having a lot of caveats and problems with it.

So I give her the example of oil prices rising in Asian trading, which is a news article on cnn.com, and the title is oil prices rise in Asian trading and it's got some some lengthy URL at cnn.com, and it turns out that actually about 16%.
Of the time, A tag will actually be in the title, so 1/6 of the tags that we looked at and we sort of randomly sampled about 20,000 posts to do so.

Evaluation on in about 1/6 of the cases the tag was actually in the title, so in this case that would mean oil prices might tag this, and that seems deeply problematic to us because, you know, search engines are already zone waiting titles and information retrieval systems have been sold.
Winning titles forever, and so those tags seem essentially useless to us.
There might be some emphasis, but it.
It seems like a relatively relatively problematic for tags.
The second thing we looked at was the percentage of tags that were obviate it by knowing what the domain was.
So if you look at cnn.com, there are certain tags that could apply to everything@cnn.com.
So an example is news or CNN and in about 1/5 of cases the tags that people apply are actually tags that could apply to the entire domain, so this isn't as bad as the title in that you know.

The title is the title suggests that all you have to do is just zone with the title, but if you're a search engine, you could probably pay somebody to label domains much more efficiently than you could get users to label these URLs for you, so this also seems problematic.
The other four things are less problematic.

The first one is that in 50% of the cases the tag is in the page text, so at the very least, this suggests that that tags are not totally divorced in terms of what content they have from the actual text of the page.

It may suggest that you can predict the tag based on the page text, or it may suggest, depending on whether you're more optimistic, it may suggest the tags might provide a good summary of the content of the page, so they might draw attention to certain pieces of text that you might.
Not otherwise pay attention to.
The final well, the other the final text thing that we looked at was extend.
Text so.
We looked at, you know, all these things.
The Backlink text, the page text in the Forward Link text, an actually when we talk about Backlink text we don't just mean the anchor text or the text that's around the anchor that points at the URL.
We actually mean all of the surrounding.
The entire text of the page that points at the page in question, and.
So we looked at all of that extended text Ann in 80% of the cases the tag was there.

So the example here is inflation, so it might be that somebody posts A blog entry about inflation and this is a relevant news article that is related to inflation but might not have bothered to state the connection.
So that's extended text, and that's probably less problematic.
It might be harder to Wade through the, you know, 10s of thousands or hundreds of thousands of words to figure out that tag applies.
The last two we actually thought would be more problematic than they ended up being so.
We looked at whether tags were irrelevant to the actual content or subjective to the actual content, and neither of these is very common.
About 7% of the time.
The tag is totally irrelevant, so Stanford doesn't seem to have very much to do with oil prices rising in Asian trading, for example.
In a funny is is sort of tag that could apply if somebody thought this was a funny funny article, but it's going to be very dependent on the person, but both of these are sort of minimal.

So a big complaint about tagging has been, you know that it's subjective and that you know people are just adding junk and that seems to be relatively rare, at least in in this particular tagging system.
So.

The conclusions of this worker that social bookmarking URLs are new and recent, and so it may make a lot of sense to modify the way that you're crawling either to get URLs that you haven't already previously indexed or to more frequently update the URLs that seem to be recently modified based on getting posted to delicious or other social bookmarking sites.
But on the other hand, the tags may be redundant for all sorts of reasons, so at least in the title and domain case it seems to be the case that those tags are.
Really not very helpful.
You know you already know a lot of that information, and it's not.
Terribly valuable.
Social bookmarking is a large phenomenon and as I said it's got millions of users.
It you know, 100 maybe 100 million bookmarks and a single one.
But it's not nearly as large as the web and.
And finally, despite this, the relevant URLs are well represented in terms of relevancy for web search or relevancy.
For, you know, wanting one of the most recent material on the web and popular tags overlap with popular queries.

So our basic conclusion here is that although these systems are relatively small and might not be able to impact web search heavily at this point, it they nonetheless will probably have a disproportionate impact to their size.

That's my talk and I'll take any questions.
Any questions for the speaker?
Hi nice work.
Could you go back to 1 slide or the one you were just on?

Yeah there, so I assume that the numbers obviously don't add up to 100, so I assume, for example, if a term is in the extended text that made it can also be in the title, and you're not differentiating that.
I wasn't clear, sorry if I missed this, just how you were what?
How larger sample was and how you were determining things like irrelevant.
Could you elaborate on that?
So actually I sort of glossed over this since I was combining it, but the title, the page text in the extended text, we took a random sample of about 20,000.
Hosts an we looked at, you know we had all this other crawled page text and we tokenized it and double checked to see whether it was in all of that text for the whole domain.
Irrelevant and subjective results.
We did a small scale user study with about 10 users an that's how we got the result.
Though for the domain result we actually verified it in a second way, which was we did prediction based on domain so, but that's something I've skipped over for this talk.
Oh, I mean the it's in terms of posts, but it's 20,000 posts 10 people left at 20,000 posts.
Oh no, they looked at 150 pages each.
Any other questions?
I actually had a question which was about the you get information about how many tags have been created by users.
I think it's probably more or less a transformation of the number of bookmarks.

I think the average is about 2 1/2 bookmarks per post, so if you're seeing 120,000 posts per day, you're seeing probably about 2 1/2 times that many tags per day, but many of them may overlap with previous tags that are already in the system and stuff like that.
Any other questions?
OK, well let's thank our speaker.
